answer_html: Thus, by using the elasticity formula above, we get \(\epsilon = -1/3\).
answer_latex:
Thus, by using the elasticity formula above, we get
$\epsilon = -1/3$.
hints_html: Remember that the derivative \(dq/dp\) at \(p=2\) is the same as the slope of the tangent line at \(p=2\).
hints_latex:
Remember that the derivative $dq/dp$ at $p=2$ is the same as the slope
of the tangent line at $p=2$.
hints_raw: Remember that the derivative <math>dq/dp</math> at <math>p=2</math> is the same as the slope of the tangent line at <math>p=2</math>.
question: 5 (a)
sols_html:
We can calculate the slope of the line by using two points on the line, say \((0,8)\) and \((8,0)\). These two points give us a slope of \(-1\).

Because the line is tangent to the graph at \((p=2,q=6)\) and its slope is \(-1\), we know that \(\frac{dq}{dp} = -1\) at \((2,6)\).

Thus, by using the elasticity formula above, we get \(\epsilon = \frac{p}{q} \frac{dp}{dq} = \frac{2}{6} (-1) = -1/3\).
sols_latex:
We can calculate the slope of the line by using two points on the line,
say $(0,8)$ and $(8,0)$. These two points give us a slope of $-1$.

Because the line is tangent to the graph at $(p=2,q=6)$ and its slope is
$-1$, we know that $\frac{dq}{dp} = -1$ at $(2,6)$.

Thus, by using the elasticity formula above, we get
$\epsilon = \frac{p}{q} \frac{dp}{dq} = \frac{2}{6} (-1) = -1/3$.
sols_raw:
We can calculate the slope of the line by using two points on the line, say <math>(0,8)</math> and <math>(8,0)</math>.  These two points give us a slope of <math>-1</math>.  

Because the line is tangent to the graph at <math>(p=2,q=6)</math> and its slope is <math>-1</math>, we know that <math>\frac{dq}{dp} = -1</math> at <math>(2,6)</math>.  

Thus, by using the elasticity formula above, we get <math>\epsilon = \frac{p}{q} \frac{dp}{dq} = \frac{2}{6} (-1) = -1/3</math>.
statement_html:
In the following figure, the curved graph is a demand curve where q is the demand and p is the price in dollars. The straight line is the tangent line to this demand curve at the point (p,q) = (2,6). Recall that the price elasticity of demand is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \epsilon(p) = \frac{p}{q} \frac{dq}{dp}\end{aligned}\]

(a) Comput \(\epsilon(2)\), the elasticity at price \$2.
statement_raw:
In the following figure, the curved graph is a demand curve where ''q'' is the demand and ''p'' is the price in dollars. The straight line is the tangent line to this demand curve at the point ''(p,q) = (2,6)''. Recall that the price elasticity of demand is given by

:<math>
\epsilon(p) = \frac{p}{q} \frac{dq}{dp}
</math>

:[[File:Math Exam Resources Courses MATH104 December2011 Question 5 (a).jpg|400px]]


'''(a)''' Comput <math>\epsilon(2)</math>, the elasticity at price $2.
